column11: Review Text
Easy hike with breathtaking views. Recommended for families with young children. Visa/MasterCard accepted at the entry gate.

For us it was a nice walk just under 2 hours. We were the first and went the round left. Worlds End, well. Nice view, thank God we were there alone... Baker's case nice to watch too. We were already met by the masses...

column8: Overpriced admission for a circular route
column11: Certainly a great way, but I don't find the price justified. Especially being up at 06:30 is just not worth it. The path is beautiful, the view is also, but simply not worth the money.

column8: Friends and family visit to World's End and the Horton Plains
column11: I visited the Worlds End on the Horton Plains after many years with friends and family from overseas. We enjoyed the track and the variety of flora and fauna along the way. The walking track has been well designed to capture this. However,  compared to the past the walking track has been extended and took us over 6 hours to complete which was only abour 4 hours in the past. The extension now includes the mini worlds end , the great worlds end and Bakers Fall. Visitors need to prepare for this which we did not do and therefore it was challenging. Cost for foreigners is unfair, cost about Rs 30K for 3 people and a vehicle. For locals it is free. Access road to the start of Worlds End from Nuwaraeliya is pretty scary, very windy, narrow, in poor condition and remote. This is over an hour of driving.

column8: A Guide’s Insight: The Breathtaking Beauty of World’s End in Sri Lanka
column11: World’s End in Sri Lanka is an extraordinary destination, and guiding visitors to this breathtaking viewpoint is always a thrilling experience. Located in the Horton Plains National Park, World’s End offers one of the most stunning panoramas in the country, and witnessing it firsthand never fails to impress. As a guide, I find that the journey to World’s End is as captivating as the destination itself. The trek through Horton Plains, with its rolling grasslands and diverse flora and fauna, sets the stage for the dramatic view that awaits at the end. The crisp, cool air and the lush landscape create an invigorating experience, making the hike to World’s End truly rewarding. The highlight of the visit is, of course, the sheer drop at World’s End. Standing on the precipice, visitors are treated to an awe-inspiring view of the valley below, with a seemingly endless expanse stretching out to the horizon. On clear days, the view is nothing short of spectacular, offering a glimpse of the far-off lowlands and a sense of being on the edge of the world. One of the most rewarding aspects of guiding at World’s End is sharing the rich natural history and significance of Horton Plains with visitors. The park is home to a range of endemic species and unique ecosystems, and explaining the ecological importance of the area adds depth to the experience. From the diverse birdlife to the rare flora, the park’s natural beauty is a key part of the adventure. The trek to World’s End is also a fantastic opportunity for visitors to appreciate the importance of conservation and the delicate balance of Sri Lanka’s highland ecosystems. Engaging with travelers about the park’s efforts to preserve its unique environment helps foster a greater appreciation for the natural world. For anyone seeking a memorable adventure in Sri Lanka, World’s End is a must-visit destination. Its dramatic scenery, combined with the rich natural and cultural context, makes it a standout experience. Join us on a trek to World’s End and witness the breathtaking beauty of Sri Lanka’s highlands like never before.

Don't miss it. For so many reasons, apart from the expense of the entry to the National Park, this will be one of the highlight experiences of your trip to Sri Lanka. From the check for plastics by rangers before you walk, the wildlife, the scenery, the all encompassing experiences of this longish walk are all unforgettable. Just do it!

This was one of the more anticipated things on my list for the tour that I was on in Sri Lanka. Make no mistake, the complete walk is quite a trek. World's End is about 4 kms from the car park and there are a numbver of rocks to walk over but it is not too bad. Take shoes with a good tread because there are a lot of very small loose round stones that are easy to slide on. I would say that it would be about a 3 out of 5 fitness trek. You can either go back the way you came or continue on to see Bakers Falls and then continue to the car park where you start. The round trip is about 9.5 kms. It will take the average person about 2.5 to 3 hours to complete but that also depends on your fitness level, how many stops you do to take photos, catch your breath or rest your legs. Is it worth the trek to see World's End? In my opinion it isn't however the sense of achievement is well worth it and I am very pleased that I did do it. There is only one World's End on the planet so you could look at it as a bucket list thing to do. The reason I said it wasn't is because it is a 900 meter drop from where you are at the sign to the bottom but you cannot see the distance. There is no viewing platform and this was why I was so dissapointed. The view of the hills and surrounding area is amazing so your trek is not wasted. As you will see from my photos, there is a slab of concrete on the ground saying World's End and then the next photo is just to the left of the sign. There are no barriers so you have to be very aware of that. Bakers Falls is beautiful. There had not been a lot of rain there lately so apparently there was not as much water flow as usual.
Amazing trail that needs to be done at sunrise to get the best views. We also saw a leopard on the way up to the park
Safety and fun, trust and responsibility we carry with you. This is one of the joyous moments of our journey.

column8: Hard walk in the cloud Forrest to World's end, little world's end and Baker falls
column11: Walk through the grasslands and cloud Forrest to the top of a massive cliff. Views down valley to sea are weather dependant. It was well wet fir our circular walk of 9km. Mainly rain and in the cloud which is common. We heard monkeys and saw spotted deer. Some bird life but limited. Walking is difficult. Uneven oath climbs and falls. Not for the unfit. One toilet on way round and in car park.

The world’s end is a must-visit trail in Sri Lanka to enjoy the best sceneries of the hill country. The weather is unpredictable in this area and views can be covered with mist and fog at any moment. We visited the World’s end in morning, as early as we could to capture stunning photographs with panoramic views. We enjoyed the best weather conditions and lovely panoramic views until faraway areas.

One of the hot spot within Horton Plains National Park (UNESCO World Heritage) with entrance fee of LKR3,850 per person. Breathtaking views and it is advisable to reach early before 9am in order to enjoy the mountainous view. Warm clothing, packed breakfast, good walking shoes and drinking water are recommended. Great hiking place for 4-5 hours. A must for nature lovers!

This is unbelievable location over tough walikn path leading to a peak and you are almost among the clouds ..sorroundings are stunning and its a place to visit in sri lanka. You can view city about 30 -40 miles away from this location if the visibility is clear. ITS much better tgan 0 point in India .

My partner and I visited Worlds End last week. It’s worth the long drive from Ella to get to. Worlds End waterfalls are impressive. Be careful when taking photos. It can be slippery. When we went it wasn’t too busy but as the season goes on it’s going to be very busy. Wear good comfy walking shoes. Set off early before it gets too hot. Don’t overdo it but enjoy. Catch the sunrise if you can.

We did the 9km circuit, if you enjoy bush walking this is a nice experience The track is rocky and wet, some of it is through a creek bed So wear appropriate shoes Join the chaos and go early arrive at the park at 6am with the rest of the crowd But you do avoid the heat of the day and the crowds disperse They are very strict on what you can bring into the park - no plastic bags, chewing gum etc The park is in pristine condition A variety of plant life, with jungles and plains No wildlife spotted and the view was okay Very hazy

It was a pleasant walk through the national park. We were even fortunate to have perfect weather all day. Not too crowded despite peak.season (new years eve). The view from world's end and little world's end is rather lovely, but I wouldn't call it spectacular. On the contrary, I'd argue that anyone who's done some hiking in the mountains anywhere would probably have experienced far more spectacular scenery than this. And the hike through the grasslands afterwards isn't exactly fantastic either. Yes, it's nice, serene and quiet, but the views are nothing special. We saw birds, heard some monkeys and we saw a couple of deer at the parking lot... A long day. Can't say it was time (and money, cause it's pretty expensive) well spent.
it is one of the coldest places in Sri Lanka, Beautifull environment with fresh air, you have to walk about 7 k.m to finish the journey
This is the point where the plateau falls dramatically to lower ground.  It is quite dramatic and affords decent views - but is overhyped and very busy

At Horton Plains the walk taking in Little Worlds End, Worlds End and Baker's Falls is about 9.5km and takes about 3 hours with photo stops. The walking track varies in difficulty and water running off the hill along the tracks creates quite slippery conditions. Progress was slow and steady, often dealing with people coming back from World's End or those pushing from behind. After nearly an hour we arrive at Little World's End observation deck, joined by my fellow tour group and about 20 others. We enjoy a break taking photos and then continue onto World's End. The track is more open and easier to walk and within 30 minutes we arrive at World's End, so named because of the 800 metre sheer drop to the valley below. It is advisable to take the left walking loop to World's End and aim to be there by mid to late morning because later in the day the clouds often push up the mountain and spoil any views.
Yes you will forget everything when you see the view point of it very faraway the life will be in the top of the hill with you and the nature.
Nice views of mountains from here if you are lucky to get clear skies. But you have to pay 3,500 SLR and hike through 12km or extremely rough terrain to get there. Totally not worth it at all.

We left Nuwara Eliya at 04'45 - quite early! But then we got to see the sunrise on the way, and there was no stress on the hike. The view is amazing! The hike is quite easy, If you fell like a bit more challenging walk, continue straight at Little World's End and climb the top and continue around the hill.
one way, two destinations, that worlds end and Horton plain, here very nice climate & amazing place.

The worlds end is about 3.5 KM from where the cars are allowed. It was a wonderful walk. In total it was 7KM but worth the walk. There are nice sceneries and waterfalls on the way. Make sure you wear a strong hiking shoe.
This 3 hour walk is not challenging and the reward of worlds end is very unpredictable due to weather. Baker falls very nice, a little over crowded. Tuk Tuk: Rs 2500 return Ticket entry is Rs 3500 pp

We set off at 5am with thunderstorms, as we approached the park there were people turning back as the weather was bad, still raining heavily. We, however, decided to carry on, this was a great decision as when we got to both little and World’s end the views were well worth the risk. Get there early and take the trail that bends to the left first.

As per the other reviews, the only thing I would add Spend more time here, relax and enjoy Most tourist spend 2-3 hours here this park needs more. Quite a drive from the town, also adds to the excitement of this park, and fantastic views
You must visit this place. This is at the end of Horton Plains National Park. It is also a cool place and you have go there by walk. It is full of natural beauty.

I have written a desperate review on Horton Plains, explaining my perspective on the horrifically challenge hike which precedes arriving at world end! World’s end is an absolute breath taking experience, and ultimately, worth the effort of the soul destroying walk to get there! For me it’s a once in a lifetime visit, and I will never feel the need to do it again, but if you have the opportunity, I would definitely go and see the natural beauty of Sri Lanka at worlds end! Hiking boots and a waterproof, along with a large bottle of water are essential!!

50% of the Horton Plains Trek is done, & u come to this place.. either u start from left to right or right to left, this comes in the center !! completely foggy, u see mist coming up from the valley below & everything in front of u disappears in the Fog !! sit here for few minutes, hv ur food, u will have some good memories to take back home !!

Setting out to go here was a bit of a mystery as really didn't know a lot about it only that it was about a 9 km walk that was easy going. Not quite as easy as made out to us! We went by tuk tuk (quite good fun even if a little snug as there was 3 of us) and left Nuwara Eliya at 6am. It took about an hour to get there. If taking a tuk tuk wrap up warm.  We froze! It was extremely cloudy and raining when we left. Thought about not going but local tuk tuk driver insisted it woukd be ok on Horton Plains. Arrived and still covered in cloud but he still insisted it would clear. Cost 8000 rupees (£40) entrance for 2 adults and  1 child in a tuk tuk to enter the park. Pricing seem confusing and not sure if the charge different for different vehicles. Well the driver was right. After starting to walk the cloud lifted and we had amazing views. Got quite hot so glad I wore shorts even if I froze on the way.  By the time we got to World End we had an amazing view. We then continued to Bakers Falls. More difficult to walk as that part is a path is through the forest so climbing upwards and over tree routes was slippery. Took about 3 1/2 hours to walk but was worth it. Just make sure sensible footwear is worn and layers of light clothes. We would have baked in jeans! You can't take plastic bags or wrappers into the park. However you can take plastic water bottles in. You just have to remove all the plastic labels from them first which they do if you haven't already.
Wow. I do not know how to explain the beauty of this wonderful place. The journey to worlds end does not tiring because of the heavenly surrounding.

It's worth when I had trekking more than 4 km to here. You can enjoy the spectacular view with full of mountains covered by green color and blue sky. The weather is cool and I really like it. Travel here and you never regret.
When you arrive at the end of a path to be faced with a 800m SHEER drop and panoramic views across the valley,  it is such a shame that the misty weather gets in the way.   Otherwise this is amazing.

I had the chance to visit this amazing place with my family, well ... i will not suggest to visit in April as it was very windy and still cold but this was the only chance that we can visit so we went. The place is amazing as in we were all mesmerized despite the cold. I cant share much about the place as due to the cold we didnt stay long but it is definitely worth the visiting.

When you reach the "end" you realize how high up the plateau that is Horton's actually is. A little town way down on the valley can be spotted.  With it came a cell phone signal.  Something absent in most of park.

Once you reach on the top of the hill, then you feel it was worth treking these many miles to reach here. Awesome weather, best scenic beauty and you will come across various species there. This place is the best attraction in Nuwara Eliya.

We hiked the World's End circuit and took our time visiting mini World's End, World's End, and Baker's Falls.  It was a pleasant walk (not difficult, but hiking shoes recommended) through really interesting forest/grassland habitat.  The geology of the area is fascinating.  The views are nice and the falls are OK.  The one drawback of the area is the entrance fee.  It is steep ~$25USD) for the experience.  I felt that was too high for a day hike.

We arrived at Horton Plains at 6am the whole walk took us 3 hours, we chose the left route so did Mini Worlds End first then Worlds End then Bakers Falls. It was quite an easy walk, did get slightly tired at certain bits. We forgot to bring trainers and socks so did the walk in flip flops...wasn't the best idea as in the morning it was freezing!!! Warmed up after the sun came up though. I would recommend wearing trainers or walking boots. When we got to Worlds End there was no one there which was lovely as we had the place to ourselves for around 15 mins. It did get very very busy all at once and there is no railings so you can go right up to the edge, quite scary but was a fantastic view! Deffinatley worth a visit.  The first part of the walk on the left route was quite rocky going downhill but nothing too extreme so can be done taking your time if your not too sure. People of all ages did the walk. There is a pool of water after or before Bakers Falls depending which way you start the walk, it's got a small waterfall going into it, we had a quick swim in it, was lovely but very very cold!!!! If you don't mind the cold go for it as was a beautiful setting. Hortons Plains was very out the way with not much around and was quite hard to get to...we drove ourselves in a tuk tuk so it would probably be easier in a nice warm van with a driver! Overall we had a lovely morning and the views were fantastic! It's best to get there early before the mist comes up and hides the view! Deffinatley worth going!

Horton Plains National Park is a very beautiful park; however,1)  it takes a long time to get to; 2) it's very, very expensive with the entry fee and high visitor tax; 3) it was overcrowded with bus loads and bus loads of other tourists -- huge camera lenses, selfie sticks, loud voices.  We have nice hiking available to us where we live for free.  We hike to reconnect and find peace and oneness with nature.   This unfortunately wasn't possible because of the high volume of tourists.  Unfortunately, can't recommend.
One's a life visit the place.. So fantastic viwe and you must be thear at erly morning at 07.30 by any vehical it was gret..

The Worlds End is in the middle of the National Park. The trail is about 10 kilometers and you get to see the big and the little worlds end. Great for taking amazing pictures and of course to enjoy the beautiful environment of Sri Lanka!!!
If you wake up in the early morning than you can see from this place great mountain views and you feel like in the end of the world.
You will witness the beautiful sceneries during a very clear day. It is like 4000 feet below deep end you see thro crystal clear water. Very risky to go near, however it is a must see place

View was spectacular , and when the sun goes down ...  i just even cant explain the feeling.  Food was great and the staff was very helpful to provide us with everything we need. The Natural pool is a added feature , however if you are not a fan of liquor i suggest not to dip in the pool as you might get hypothermia... All around good experience how ever they should think about the pricing ..

The most amazing place in Srilanka.located in the protected area in Horton plains(Nuweraeliya).All journey you have to walk nearly 10 KM. April to September is the very good time. In between the day if it is mist you can't see the most memorable view of the end. Try to avoid weekends and public holidays in Sri Lanka . Also, there is an option you have to go by train till ohiya and from that station there is a footpath if you are a crazy about hiking. Also, don't forget to go baker's falls as well while you walking.

If you're willing to cough up the entrance fee (around 2500-3000 rupees), and you're lucky enough to see the view, then World's End is definitely worth it! We left our accommodation at around 5am, wanting to get to the park early to avoid crowds and see world's end before the mist set in. Luckily our view wasn't obscured by mist, and we reached both viewing points before other tourists groups, so we had it to ourselves for a few peaceful minutes!  The walk isn't strenuous, but definitely wear runners!

This place of nature is really a gem in Sri Lanka. The entrance fee is quite high (2000rp - in contrast locals pay 60rp) but the area is very wonderful to walk and look at the different flora which can be discovered. Unfortunately we did not see very well from the Worlds End and Little Worlds End as there were very much fog (even though we were starting the hike at 6:15). It all depends on luck and the weather conditions. Still we enjoyed the walk very much and we would recommend it for anyone in the area.

The most amazing place in Srilanka.located in the protected area in Horton plains(Nuweraeliya). About 4000ft drop from a cliff. Better get there before sunset as the whole area will be covered with mist.

We were picked up by our driver at about 8.30am and drove the entire time to the start of the walk in dense fog.We wondered whether we should have been going.Luckily as we commenced the walk it cleared up and the conditions were perfect the entire way.We had heard that there can be huge queues for entry tickets but we didn't not experience that.Teh walk is not hard and you see small children and mothers holding wee babies going around.Teh views are very nice as is the waterfall.The day we went was part of a long weekend holiday and as we were leaving many more Sri Lankan people were arriving to do the walk.We found out that the day before 600 vehicles had transported 9000 people up to do the walk! So it can be very crowded.Check those holiday dates and try to avoid if you can.Overall this was a lovely walk and I am sure if there had been no fog that the scenery getting to the park would have also been very nice.
This is a truly awesome place. Worlds end is situated in the Horton Plains national park. If you take the circular trail from the park information center you can reach after a walk of hour or two.
it's beautiful place filled with greenery cool & calm & quite is must visit place if you are traveling to mountains areas.

After an early start and a drive up a mountain road you finally reach the entrance to the Park.  You can walk a loop of Mini World’s End, World’s End and Baker’s Fall, all of which are well worth seeing.

Horton Plains is a beautiful, silent, strange world with some excellent hikes in the shadows of Sri Lanka’s second- and third-highest mountains, Kirigalpotta (2395m) and Totapola (2359m). The ‘plains’ themselves form an undulating plateau over 2000m high, covered by wild grasslands and interspersed with patches of thick forest, rocky outcrops, filigree waterfalls and misty lakes. The surprising diversity of the landscape is matched by the wide variety of wildlife. The plateau comes to a sudden end at World’s End, a stunning escarpment that plunges 880m. Unless you get there early the view from World’s End is often obscured by mist, particularly during the rainy season from April to September. The early morning (between 6am and 10am) is the best time to visit, before the clouds roll in. That’s when you’ll spy toy-town tea plantation villages in the valley below, and an unencumbered view south towards the coast. In the evening and early morning you’ll need long trousers and a sweater, but the plains warm up quickly, so take a hat for sun protection. The weather is clearest January to March.

If you are in Sri Lanka or coming Sri Lanka for a holiday this is a must go place. far different from coastal area really cool and breezy weather. lots of walk and  scenery.  when it misty( not too much) you can fulfill your dream of touching clouds :) :) can be bit expensive but its really really worth. make sure come with a good vehicle. also TRY TO COME HERE EARLY AS POSSIBLE IN THE DAY

Hi all.. had written a review on horton plains national park earlier, but i think writing a review on worlds end would be more useful to fellow travellers. I made the trip in Jun 16 with wife and my sis in law. my experience & suggestions are as follows Worlds end point is one of the points in horton plains national park, for going to worlds end, you need to be prepared to walk for 8.7 kms & complete the horton plains hike... 1) stay and getting there Horton plains are grassy lands and about 1800 mts from sea level... For going there you need to stay the night at nuwara eliya and start at abt 5:30 am next morning for the plains which are abt 40 kms from nuwara eliya We stayed at a budget hotel called ashford and got a room for lkr 5500.. Check their website and call them directly for a booking to get a good deal (Hotel ashford +94522235771)... If not this there are other budget places in nuwara eliya which you can opt for... But staying back is a must for this trip. 2) Transport The plains are abt 40 kms from nuwara eliya and most of the road is very narrow and has steep upward slopes... You will get vans and jeepa who will take you there and bring you back. The cost is 3.5 to 5 k lkr... There is also an option of going by tuk tuk but i suggest to avoid it given the cold winds and tuk tuk also costing abt 3k lkr... Most hotel receptions will have a contact of a van so its easily available. You can also go there in your own car... But given the narrow and steep roads i suggest you take your car only if its a 4x4 or has a good ground clearance... The parking charges for car at the gate is 250lkr. giving your our guys contact who took us there in a jeep and charged us 3.5k lkr (herath +94779149563) 3) ticket fees I was myself very confused abt the ticket prices and didnt get firm info on this... So im clarifying the tickets cost for the benefit of all Ticket cost for foreign passport holders is approx 3800lkr and this is common for all countries The local ticket is just 60lkr and you can get this ticket if you have a residence visa in srilanka and are carrying your passport with you 4)The hike Once inside and at the start point you have 2 routes to do the hike that is from the left or the right of the starting stone.. The starting stone shows the distances of all major points from the start in both directions.. The total hike is 8.7 kms First of all.. Dont leave the hike midway and come back... You will end up walikng the same distance as completing the hike if you do that. My suggestion is to take the hike from the right like we did cause it slopes down few kms from the start point upto bakers fall where there is a serious slope down. If you do the hike from the left you will be climbing up these last few kms which will be very very tiring. Most tourist take the hike from the left as the worlds end point is near from there... But trust me the right side is best for saving up energy and doing a comfortable hike. 5) the points The 2 best points in the hike are the worlds end and bakers fall Bakers fall is a nice big and peaceful water fall that makes for a great photo stopover Worlds end is just a magnificent view where there is a sudden drop of 870mts and great view of the adjoining mountains and lake. The vertical drop can not be captured in a photograph hence all the pics we see of the place do not amaze us a lot.. Its is best advised to reach the worlds end point by 7-7.30 am so you must start the hike early at around 6 am from the entrance... If you reach the worlds end point late then it gets a cloud cover and nothing much is visible from the point. Along the hike you will see some sambar deers grazing along and if your lucky you can get a snap with some if they are close to you. The total hike took us a good 3 hours with stopovers and it was very very cold and windy in the morning when we started... So i strongly suggest you go there with a set of warm wear. While returning back to base... You must stop over at pattipola train station which is the highest altitude station in srilanka and also ambewella newzeland farm which again make for a good photo stop. All in all... The experience of walking the grass lands along with deer's, mist and beautiful views is just exhilarating and cant be described in words. I would rate my experience as a 9/10 and just taking away a point for the trouble involved in getting there and the money required to be spent and the fact that by the time you get back to the hotel by 12:30 pm you immediately have to check out leaving you tired from the hike and deprived of sleep the previous night. But still its a must do if you are planing a nuwara eliya visit. All the best to all fellow travellers :)
The view is not much lesser than the Worlds End. Just 500 m away from the Great Worlds End. This is just 300 M shorter than the Great Worlds End.

Great outdoor activity - good to get out in nature and enjoy some cool sri lankan air. The walk isn't too hard, with a few main stops - worlds end and the water falls. Only took us about 2.5 hours to do the loop. Bit expensive, but worth it. An environment worth supporting and protecting.

Must, must do! Just must do. World's end is a viewing spot in The Horton Plains National park which is one of the most beautiful locations in Sri Lanka. It is a 9km circle which has three stops along the way – Mini World’s End, World’s End and Baker’s Fall. The trail is easy (will short patches of incline along the way which are easy to climb) and breathtakingly beautiful. Finish it off with a cup of tea and biscuits at the canteen overlooking the plains. On more practical information, the entrance to the plains is an hour’s drive from Nuwara Elliya (approximately) and the tickets are slightly expensive (but worth every penny). Take the route on the left (which reaches baker’s fall last) since it’s a better way to circle the plains. Also, if you get tired halfway and feel the urge to turn back – don’t, because even if you turn back you’ll have the same distance to cover and you’ll miss the trail on the other side.

We had a nice but not sunny day at the Horton Plains. Started at 5 am from N.E.by taxi for 4000 LKR and reached the entrance to the park at 6 am which is also the opening hour of the park. 6300 LKR are not a bargain, but if it helps to preserve the area I am on with it. Reached the drop after almost an hour walk. We had not more than ten minutes before the clouds came and visibility went down to almost zero. Lucky! Don't expect too much wildlife. A few birds, mainly too far away even for a 300mm tele lens, some deers and a kind of monkey, that's it. Nevertheless the scenery is stunning. It was the second visit after 8 years, but things didn't change at all. Worth the visit and the 3 hours walk (can be 4 hours of you take it s bit more easy)

The worlds end is a part of the horton track. It's wort seing this place! The clouds can be seen under you so it's pretty powerful experience. The walk to worlds end is very beautiful. A good getaway for the day. Being water and snacks.
The view is worth it and a great hike. You have to get here early to miss the crowds and the mist. Mist rolls in at about 9am so it pays to get in as early as you can!
Hiking the Worlds End was a highlight of my trip. Beautiful nature and spectacular view from the mountain!
This is a must visit if you are on your way to Nuwara Eliya. One of the best hikes in the area and must not miss it if you are a  hiking fan..

I expected much more for this kind of money - you have to pay ticket by person and also a group fee (and for transport of course) - in summary it takes for us (couple) around 13k! The national park is amazing, but there are so much people that you cannot enjoy it for yourself - there is only one way (resp. round way) you have to go (cca 10km). In summary - overpriced trip to see plains like in England. But the mountain views is beautiful.

the worlds end trek is the perfect way to start your day. Ensure that you reach the world’s end entry gate by 6am. It is a 10kms trek and you need to be at the world’s end view point by 8am to ensure that the mist doesn’t cover the entire view. The best place to stay for doing the world’s end trek is Ohiya. It is half an hour away from Ohiya. If you stay at Nuwara eliya city, you might end up paying huge amount to tuk tuk guy along with losing your morning sleep as it is pretty far from Nuwara eliya. Take the left turn on the bifurcation so that you can cover the places in the order -> mini world’s end -> world’s end -> Baker’s fall. The right path is longer and takes you through baker’s fall first, which you can cover anytime. You need to ensure that you cover the World’s end before the mist covers it.

We woke up at 5am to get to Hortain Plains, which was well worth it, as even though people were around, it wasn't too crowded. We took the path left towards Mini Worlds End, Worlds End and then Bakers Falls to ensure we got to the two key viewing points before the clouds came in. The walk was fun, going over a few different terrains. I would recommend trainers at least. The most challenging but was a dried river bed, walking down/through big boulders. The viewing points were great. It wasn't too crowded, so it was nice to sit down and have some breakfast. It's worth taking the steps down to Bakers Fall too. When we arrived at 6am it was 9 degrees, by the time we finished it was 30 degrees, so make sure you dress in layers, take water and plenty of suncream. Worth doing the 9km walk. You can get similar views elsewhere, but it was great with a fun walk too.

You have 2 beautiful view points in this nice and pretty easy walk of 2 to 3 hours (depending your pace and time you take at the view points). I would recommend you to walk first to the viewing points, that is the left branch at the t-junction just after the entrance. The only con of this way is that you have to most difficult part of the route on your way back, but the pro is that you see the viewing points at first and then is the chance of a good view the best. You you must have been on both viewing points before 10 am, because on most days the clouds roll in between 9 and 10 am and this will obscure the view completely. If you take the left branch at the T-junction then you will visit the little world's end first and the world's end second, so you save the best view for the last. The walk to worlds end from the entrance is about 1 hour depending your pace. On the way back from the viewing point (if you walk a round trip) you can also visit a waterfall and you will walk through the beautiful nature of the horton's plains.
We walked from the main entrance via the mini worlds end, full worlds end and the falls on the way back.  Approx 6 mile walk, stunning scenery.

We loved walking Horton National Park and seeing the spectacular views of World's End as well as the rolling hills and waterfall. The walk itself was also very pleasant and relatively easy though the paths are quite poor due to the rains. There's also quite a hill and navigating lots of tree roots to get to the falls. Otherwise, it's a brilliant day out. Tips: - Take a packed breakfast / lunch, lots of water and wear plenty of sunscreen / sun protection as there's nothing once you're in the park (though a cafeteria and some stalls outside the entrance.) - Try to arrive for gates open at 7am and take the left turn to World's End (rather than the right which will take you longer to get around the park)to ensure you arrive at World's End before 9am when the mists might set in and spoil the views (plus the coach tours seem to arrive later in the morning and they tend to be very noisy and disruptive.) - Keep an eye out as you're driving between the entry gates and walk entrance for Sambhur.
See my review of Horton Plains which includes hints/tips on visiting this beautiful natural sight. Must-see as part of a visit to Sri Lanka!

We woke up at 5:00 and left the Grand hotel at 530. It was about an hour drive to the main gate where it was very busy and cars parked everywhere. Appearently you have to get there early as mist starts rolling in at mid morning. We spent about 3 hours at a slower pace doing the circle trip. The view at the world's end is nice but nothing special in my eyes. I'm from Vancouver where we get pretty spectacular views. This is defiantly a busy place, so expect there to be crowds of people at the viewing areas. Along the trail it is not too busy.
Best place to understand about clouds forest. And the scenery was amazing.  Tracking will take nearly 2- 3 hour's.

It is indeed a must-do and we were lucky to get clear views, as it can get misty/hazy apparently. But personally I did get the feeling that it is slightly overhyped and was a little too busy and touristy when we arrived. It would be a far better and more personal experience if it were a tad quieter, and despite being a 870 metre sheer drop, the angle and perspective from the top belies this fact as one is set back from the edge. I must admit to being more of a fan of the sheer views from the Badulla to Nanu Oya train, and the beauty and intimacy of Bakers Falls later on during this hike. Still a must-do though, enjoy!

If you are spending time in the hill country - Ella, Haputale, Nuwara Eliya - there are many similar views for a $0 price tag. The sheer drop of worlds end is what makes it stand out, but if you're after the views, I found Liptons Seat and Little Adams peak just as good (or better) If you are a budget traveler, skip it. It's pricey. Almost 6000Rs for two people. If money is not an issue, and you have limited time to explore the rest of the hill area, it's a decent hike. A few tips: -When beginning the circuit, start by going LEFT. It gets you to worlds end quicker than turning right ; beating the crowds -If you are travelling by motorcycle or scooter you can store your backpack/luggage at the donut shop with a lovely man named Mohammed -Gates open at 6 am; you should start between 0600-0700 to avoid the mist

Bring your hiking shoes - the walk took us 2.5 hours and some of the path isn't paved. Woke up at 4:30am for this hike but it was well worth it - simply amazing views from Worlds End (go early before the clouds set in). Highly recommend.

Were lucky to have great warm sunny weather. The circular route takes 2-3 hours and includes "Mini" End of the World, End of the World and Bakers Falls. We arrived early in the morning because we heard that mist blocks the view by 9am. Nice hike with varying landscapes and views. See the pictures below.
Strongly advice to visit this breathtaking place. The mountain view is so beautiful. Many places to take nice pictures. Sometimes a bit overcrowded.

This was a great experience. I would liek to recommend everyone to travel here as early as possible. The sunrise was spectacular. We went in late January and for a swede the temperature was like an average summerday. Therefore, no need to dress upp like you are going to the north pole.

We stayed in Nuwara Eliya for two nights and went out to Horton plains to do the worlds end walk. We caught a tut tut out. 2500rp for the drive there, waiting for us to do the walk, then drive us back. We left at 530am for the 1 hour tut tut ride. The walk it's self is really nice and even though classified as an easy walk is difficult at times. The views at the top of Worlds end are wonderful. Photos don't do it justice. The walk is good. However we had to pay entry fee to go in the park. 2800rp each. It's not big money but considering Adams peak if free and a better experience I'd do that first. I like how the park is collecting money to help preserve Horton plains but it make for a pretty expensive day if you are going with your family. The walks good. The cost isn't!

From the park entrance you can do the worlds end loop in 3-4 hours. You see mini worlds end, worlds end, and bakers falls. Maybe you can spot some deer, giant squirrels, bear monkeys, or a leopard from a distance if you are lucky. Worth every minute.

It's an adventure to get to (we were settling in heritance tea factory c1hr30 journey), but beautiful scenery. A jeep took us up the hill, and the driver also was a guide. Not necessary to have someone, but our driver was incredibly friendly so it was nice to have company and someone to point out the best routes. We left at 5am to get there, definitely worth doing this as it is the best chance for a great view at worlds end, and it beats the local crowd (the road up is single track, extremely long and steep so preferable for the nerves to hit less traffic). We went at it was amazing sunshine, so I am sure my review would be less favourable if it was bleak! Not one for animal watching. Negatives are that the price is so steep for a jolly walk - £30 for two of us, plus £30 for driver exc tip (12000 rps).

My app won't let me load a picture, but this place has to be seen to be believed. It is a decent walk through Horton plains and some jungle. You arrive at "Mini Worlds End" first, which is a mere 250m vertical drop - this is impressive in itself. Worlds End is 870m and is simply stunning. Arrive early before the mist shrouds the view. We had done both viewpoints by 9am and weren't disappointed. It is worth waiting 5-10mins for the clouds to clear, something you might have to do in order to get a people free picture anyway. Well worth the walk to get here. Trainers at least needed, I wouldn't want to walk it in flip-flops. The path beyond Worlds End to Bakers Falls gets slippery and steep through the jungle.
Fog interrupts the view so it's better visit before midday. Otherwise you'll only see the path to heaven which runs through the miles of clouded hell 🌞⛅

We set off at 5am from Haputale as we had been advised to get to World's End as early as possible (the park opens at 6am) in order to get the best view.  At 10am the mist comes and there is nothing to see.  The drive up to the visitor centre and the start of the walk itself to World's End 's long and winding, through a beautiful forest coming out at the top to amazing views.  Driving across the plains there are lots of deer.  It is quite expensive to get into the park and it's worth noting that if you have a driver and / or a guide you will have to pay for them also.  The 9k walk was more difficult than I expected and trainers or walking shoes are essential.  We saw lots of people beginning the walk in flip flops and ordinary shoes and couldn't imagine how they would manage to complete it.  The walk begins with a path but then turns into a dry river bed which is very rocky and uneven. Part of the walk is also through a wooded area which means climbing up over tree roots and some of it was quite muddy.  Mini Worlds End and Worlds End itself are astounding.  There are no fences or barriers so the experience is complete.  Don't get too close if you don't like heights!!  Bakers Falls which you also pass is also really lovely and worth the little detour down the steps.

Great place to walk to from the Hortons, its the main attraction there and definitely stands to its name. The trek is long but carry ample water as there are only 2 places to eat or get things, one at the beginning and one at the top. So water is a must. Try going before the sunrise or before the fog sets in.

Ensure that you complete the Worlds End walk in an anti clockwise route. This is the more comfortable route and ensures that the later section of the walk is not all uphill. Also get here early or your views will simply consist of looking at a lot of mist. The only thing that spoils the walk is the other walkers who can at times be very, very loud, reducing the chances of you spotting any wildlife. The view from worlds end is spectacular and well worth the walk.

The world's End is located on the south western edge of the Horton Plains which is one of the greatest tourist attractions in the hill country.  For many, World's End is the coveted final destination and sole reason to be on Horton Plains whilst the Plains has its own character and appeal.  A winding  6 kilometer long trek across the plains  and through stretches of  montane forests brings one to the edge of the plains and first to the Smaller World's End and then a few hundred meters beyond on the same trail to the Greater World's End - the coveted destination. World's End is literally  a sheer drop of around 3,500 feet to a sparsely populated valley below. The view from the edge- where there is a viewing platform - on a clear day is magnificent and when the cloud cover rolls in engulfing the entire surroundings- as it often does, is  stunning. One can see a number of some of the highest mountains in Sri Lanka from here.The temperatures often plummet to around 10C and the rains are quite common. The trail that the travellers take is circuitous and on its way back will take travellers to another attraction on the plains -the Bakers Falls.

i went to mini world end (not world end) with my 1 year old on my back and my 3 years old walking with his mom and our driver. 5Km walk (2.5x2). it was almost the best thing i did in my visit to sri lanka. walking in the horton plains is so much fun. nature, animals and cold breez. and finally we reached the Mini worlds end for a breath taking view , my driver took very nice photos for us as he is advanced in photography . i loved everything about it. we could not go any further wo worlds end as my kids will become exhausted. My driver company during this walk was instrumental to its success as the 3years old might have got tired at any point. the driver carried him several times for few hunder meters. such an excellent driver  for families with kids.

Last month had gone to visit worlds end point in Srilanka with my husband . We had read earlier reviews about this point and it was among top most things to visit in Srilanka . We had paid around 7000 LKR for the entry. ( including one vehicle ) . The moment you enter , you would feel that you are amidst the clouds. It's a beautiful scene. Then from the car it takes you to a point, beyond which the walk starts. Food and drinks are not allowed inside . You would see a board to the worlds end - one can start from right as well from left . It's a walk in a circle form . At the end you would reach where you started from. The total walk is around 9-10 Kms. There is no option of eating in this path. We came across 2 washrooms though . We started from left and the path was filled with rocks. Wearing shoes is advisable but it is okay if you aren't wearing one. You will still make it as we did 😀 the journey is really beautiful , greenery everywhere . Small climbs , few jumps .. Few falls . After an hour you would reach mini worlds end. It was a nice spot. Then after around 20 min of further walk, you would reach the worlds end. Little hyped . Then after around an hour you can see bakers fall . It's a small waterfall . Even if you miss , it is okay . Then after around 1 hour you would reach back to the starting point . At these main points you just spend like few minutes , but the whole journey of 3-3.5 hours is filled with scenic beauty . It's worth a visit for sure.

World's end offers amazing views. Located inside the Horton Plains National Park its a walk of around 9kms. We reached at bit late and it was fully covered with clouds. Make sure you start the walk as early as possible to get the best views. However the walk in Horton Plains itself is a great with some beautiful views.
Easy Trail to a Great Place. Very recommended and a must for all Sri Lanka travelers. Very busy with a lot of traffic in July and August.

If you travel to Nuwera Eliya or Bandarawela, world's end is a must do.  You can drive up to Horton Plains irrespective of the route you take.  Nuwera Eliya route is more winding, but spectacular view!  Vehicles are parked after the ticket office in Horton Plains.  There after the walk starts. There are 2 routes that can be taken.  It’s recommended that you take the Baker’s Falls route to reach world’s end and then take the other route to get back to the Plains.  The total walk is 9 km.  We took 3 hours to do the whole walk, stopping at world’s end, mini-world’s end and baker’s falls.  If you are someone who would need a rest in-between, it may take upto 4 hours. Baker’s falls route is longer and tougher.  But the water fall is so breath-taking, it’s worth toughing it out!  There are places where the road to walk is just a foot path through rock formations.  There are slippery slopes and muddy patches…. But its nature at its best!! Word of advice…. When you come to the place where you need to decide which route to take, you would see a name board which is very confusing and has arrows pointing both ways.  So remember, when you stand in this ‘Y’ junction and wonder which way is the baker’s fall route, it’s on to your right!! All those people who have no respect for nature and litter this amazing, natural piece of heaven by throwing water bottles and biscuit wrappers…. Remember that you are destroying one of Sri Lanka’s most beautiful places…. This is where the world end’s and nature begins to show us how beautiful and blessed we are in Sri Lanka…. Please let’s look after our country!

The view from the top is majestic! Mountains, valleys, lakes, and even the ocean on a clear day. Be sure to arrive to Horton Plains by the opening of the gate (was at 6am in April), and make a fast stroll and only a brief stop at Little Worlds End in order to marvel this view without crowds of other people eating their packed breakfasts.

One of the best places in the world to watch the environment and scenic beauty. The view from the world's end it breathtaking. But it's very difficult to see a proper view as most of the time the view is covered with think mist. However the walkway is bit difficult and the park authorities should build basic needs proper walkway and clear road signs.
Wery expensive 5400 lkr for 2 people. We returning with nothing. And spending a lot of time to go here.

It's a lovely walk and the view is great but the price to get in is ridiculous when you know how much things are worth in Sri Lanka; consider that the entrance fee for foreigners is 2500 lkr, price for locals is 60 lkr!  Unfortunately many of the national parks seem to be overpriced, and are going to become unaffordable for the young backpackers and tourists on tighter budgets. On top of the expensive entrance fee the gate guard working on 5th January saw 4 girls as an opportunity to extort money; he didn't succeed as we are not shrinking violets but bad for an unpleasant time and tainted experience. Wear proper walking shoes especially if it's been wet. There are much better free walks around Ella (&you don't need a guide so king as there is more than one of you!)

The trek was easygoing and beautiful. All the main sites are relaxing. Before noon the weather swings are very drastic. Tip: best time is 6:00 to 9:00 in the morning. Bring bonnets and sunscreen for protection against the sun

An enjoyable nature walk,  Not daunting by most fit people's assessment but wear comfortable shoes  and not for aged, infirm, or kids that don't like exercise. Views are sensational if the clouds stay away - we had glimpses rather than consistent views. A little bit of fauna and you need to stop and listen to identify most of it. Bathroom facilities are rustic by western standards.

Worlds end is the gem of Hortons Plains and is a must visit of trekkers and nature lovers. Get early by around 6 AM and start the trek to World end to see some of the amazing views which will leave you spellbound.
It is worth a visit but the rate to get in is way too high. I get the impression the tourist attractions think everyone is loaded. It was not worth the entrance fee!

If you are a nature lover and having a good physical fitness you must see this. You have to walk up and down total of about 8 Kms. Yet walking along the pristine environment across the Horton plane is an unforgettable experience. You will come to a abrupt sharp edge of a rock below which you see the Balngoda town  which is about 4 Kms down below. It is best you reach there before 10.00 am or else it could get covered with dense mist and you might not see any thing. It could be cold. Take adequate water and and some nutritional food with you. Please do not take any polythene there and make sure you bring back your garbage.
